Legal_Provision_Violated: Provisions of the IRPA (Immigration and Refugee Protection Act)
Application_Facts: Ms. Brodrick claimed refugee protection due to domestic abuse in Nigeria
Procedural_Issue: RAD's use of reasonableness standard instead of correctness standard rendered Federal Court's role duplicative
Jurisdictional_Issue: Improper application of review standard by RAD affecting judicial hierarchy and statutory interpretation under IRPA
Decision_Outcome: RPD and RAD rejected the claim
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of case for reconsideration by a new RAD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied by RAD
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness (inappropriately applied); Correctness standard required on judicial review by Federal Court
Decision_Rationale: RAD's decision to apply reasonableness was unreasonable as it contradicted IRPA and undermined Federal Court's oversight role
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in applying a reasonableness standard to review the RPD's decision
Governing_Law: RAD decisions on the standard of review are assessed on correctness
Evidence_Assessment: Key findings were not solely based on applicant testimony
Decision_Outcome: RAD's decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant bears burden to establish refugee claim
Credibility_Factor: RPD found applicant non-credible, credibility was critical
Legal_Rule: RPD decisions require independent review unless credibility is critical
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied incorrectly; correctness standard required for RAD's review
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; referred back for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant testimony, other evidence beyond testimony
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility finding
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of RAD decision, referral for re-determination
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, decision remanded to new RAD panel
Legal_Provision: Section 74 of IRPA, Standard of Review doctrine

Application_Facts: Applicant sought refugee protection, which was denied by RPD and upheld by RAD due to alleged lack of credible evidence.
Procedural_Issue: RAD improperly used the reasonableness standard instead of recognizing its appellate role.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Stepfather's letter deemed inadmissible due to credibility and materiality concerns
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns regarding the stepfather's letter
Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection denied by RPD, upheld by RAD
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter remitted to newly constituted RAD
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied incorrectly by RAD
Standard_of_Review: Hybrid standard: reasonableness for factual findings, palpable and overriding error for legal issues
Decision_Rationale: RAD erred by applying judicial review principles rather than appellate standards; reconsideration required

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Adewole's H&C application was refused due to criminal inadmissibility and lack of updated information.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred by relying on extrinsic evidence unknown to the applicant.
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness requires disclosing evidence necessary for meaningful participation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant was aware or had access to the evidence; lawyer received request for updates but did not respond; consent to communication with Institut existed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in relying on extrinsic evidence of which the applicant was unaware
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on Institut Philippe-Pinel letter and CTV report
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to update file despite opportunity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires reasonable opportunity to participate meaningfully; evidence must be disclosed if it affects response ability
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness due to use of undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failed to respond to request for updated information

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support reliance by immigration officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant was aware of reports and had duty to disclose relevant information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not objectively well-founded; insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection or internal flight alternative
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution fears from a gang and a municipal employee in Venezuela
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified as ignored; rather, evidence was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility standard, not balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to prove lack of state protection or impossibility of internal relocation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to report threats to police
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97, IRPA (persons in need of protection)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Extortion by gang and harassment by municipal employee
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee status by IRB
Crimes.Credibility: Partially undermined due to lack of reporting

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a), IRPA (burden of proof on claimant)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Anonymous police complaint without identifying details
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Federal Court over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detail and verification in anonymous complaint
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee or protected person
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and convincing evidence to rebut state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Anonymous complaint insufficient to prove lack of state protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repetition of demands, abuse of public office
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No physical harm reported, limited geographic threat
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, depending on enforcement context
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Personalized based on prior employment dispute
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially compromised by lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee determination

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Residency Obligations
Application_Facts: Respondent's travel document application denied due to failure to meet residency requirements; appeal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds citing mother's deteriorating health and best interests of children
Claimant_Status: Father, permanent resident seeking to maintain status despite non-compliance
Procedural_Issue: Minister argued inadequate reasoning by IAD in allowing appeal
Evidence_Used: Testimonies regarding mother's health, children's best interests, family circumstances
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence presented, but deemed sufficient by IAD
Decision_Outcome: IAD allowed the appeal on H&C grounds
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; IAD decision upheld as reasonable
Relief_Sought: Quashing of IAD's decision and dismissal of the appeal
Remedy_Sought: Court to intervene and set aside IAD's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: IAD's conclusion that father’s presence would benefit the family was justified, transparent, and intelligible; decision fell within acceptable range of outcomes

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing credibility regarding alleged rape and fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant not credible due to delays in reporting and inconsistencies; mental health evidence considered insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on alleged rape
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in narrative and delay in reporting
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; medical evidence was considered but deemed insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Mental health condition (DID) offered as explanation for inconsistencies

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator was a state actor (police officer)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant suffered from DID, which may affect memory and consistency
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution upon return to St-Vincent
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gender-based violence and abuse of power
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and potential state complicity
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior assault
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to delays and inconsistencies despite mental health diagnosis

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Aggravated sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of authority, vulnerability of victim
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Very high (aggravated assault by state actor)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization and persecution
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and systemic failure to protect
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior report to authorities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not credible due to behavioral and narrative inconsistencies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Trust by Peace Officer
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility in refugee claim involving abuse by police
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably assessed credibility of rape allegation against a police officer
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence (DID) considered but not determinative
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for claim
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in reporting, inconsistencies in account
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged rape by police officer and fear of return
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board provided transparent and justified reasoning
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn negative decision

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged false testimony in refugee proceeding
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of judicial review over credibility findings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration and internal inconsistencies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted but no proof of deliberate falsehood
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No evidence of intent to deceive; inconsistencies possibly due to trauma

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on membership in an organization
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's membership in MQM led to inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to non-compliance with admissibility requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Determination of appropriate procedure for non-disclosure of national security information
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of section 86 vs. section 87 of IRPA in judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Tribunal Record with sensitive information subject to redaction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Non-disclosure motion granted under section 87 of IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 87 of IRPA in conjunction with Federal Courts Rules 317, 318, and Rule 4
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 87 aligns better with judicial review context and allows redactions without summaries for national security

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged ties to MQM, designated as a terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security due to organizational affiliation
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Affiliation with MQM assessed as risk under immigration security grounds
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in an organization linked to terrorism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Political association alleged to support or be part of a terrorist entity
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian immigration and national security system
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Sensitive intelligence-based evidence cited by respondent
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Need to withhold parts of the Tribunal Record for national security reasons
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility based on national security
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residency and partial non-disclosure of record

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee protection but were denied by the RPD and RAD. They sought judicial review citing bias and improper standard of review.
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied a deferential standard of review instead of a complete review, contrary to its appellate role.
Credibility_Assessment: RAD applied a deferential standard to the RPD's credibility assessment, failing to conduct an independent review.
Decision_Outcome: RPD and RAD initially denied the refugee protection claim.
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed in part.
Remedy_Sought: Remand to a differently constituted RAD panel for redetermination.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Deferential standard (incorrectly applied by RAD).
Standard_of_Review: RAD must conduct a complete review of fact, law, and mixed fact and law; not merely apply reasonableness standard.
Decision_Rationale: RAD failed to fulfill its statutory duty to fully review factual and legal issues; remanded for proper appellate review.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Appeal Division (IRB-RAD)

Application_Facts: PRRA and H&C applications were denied during volatile war conditions in Sri Lanka
Decision based on undisclosed BBC articles and a UK tribunal decision later deemed invalid
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose significant new developments
Lack of reasonable consideration of evidence
Decision_Outcome: Denial of PRRA and H&C applications
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of applications by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to disclose key information and relied on invalid precedent; decision made under unreasonable circumstances due to timing amid conflict in Sri Lanka

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to alleged persecution in El Salvador but were deemed non-credible by the Board.
Misrepresentation_Element: Omissions, inconsistencies, and lack of detail in applicants' testimony
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the Board’s credibility findings
Evidence_Used: Applicants' testimony, lack of proof regarding state protection inability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear proof of state inability to protect the female applicant
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants non-credible due to omissions, inconsistencies, and lack of detail
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld; no patent unreasonableness found
Relief_Sought: Intervention by the Court to overturn Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s credibility assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness
Decision_Rationale: The Board has discretion to assess credibility; applicants' evidence was inconsistent and insufficient to prove state protection inability

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous application of PRRA risk assessment to H&C hardship analysis
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Deportee with familial ties in Canada
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Assessed under PRRA but not appropriately considered in H&C
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Not directly assessed in H&C due to error

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave after authorized stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ramirez remained in Canada beyond visa validity
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Reuse of PRRA findings in H&C assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not an issue
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conflation of PRRA risk with H&C hardship

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Fettering of discretion by reusing PRRA findings
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between entry method and protection claims
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Single immigration officer handling both PRRA and H&C
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Improper reuse of findings, lack of independent assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Removal Order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Misapplication of legal standards in H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: PRRA findings used without new evaluation
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate H&C grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements to Obtain Immigration Benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of incorrect legal standard in assessing hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not the basis of refusal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Reuse of PRRA risk analysis in H&C context
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative decision followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Conflation of H&C hardship with PRRA risk
Crimes.Legal_Standard: H&C hardship standard under s. 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of non-Canadian daughter in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of security clearance was based on irrelevant considerations and whether procedural fairness was breached
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's criminal record and continued marijuana use were assessed as relevant to subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's ongoing marijuana use and criminal history affected credibility regarding security risk
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Refusal allowed if reasonable grounds to suspect applicant may be suborned to endanger marine transportation security
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged irrelevance of marijuana use and lack of adequate notice or reasons
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal record including obstructing a peace officer
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister argued that drug use and criminal history posed a legitimate security concern
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of security clearance denial

Crimes.Crime_Name: Dangerous operation of a motor vehicle
Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Traffic-related offense with potential for harm
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Individual with criminal history and substance use
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high due to repeated offenses and substance involvement
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk of subornment in sensitive security environment
Crimes.Risk_Type: Security vulnerability due to potential coercion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Not applicable – general threat to marine transportation security
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support reasonable suspicion under regulatory standard
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, admissions of drug use
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Deemed credible and relevant by reviewing body
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's history undermined trustworthiness for security clearance
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – administrative, not criminal sentencing

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had recent drug conviction and continued marijuana use
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of notice and reasons in denial process
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal regulatory authority over marine security clearances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about reliability due to illegal drug activity
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Minister’s decision upheld
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and reinstatement of application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Drug production and use indicate susceptibility to coercion in security-sensitive context

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime under $1000
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal of security clearance denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether denial was based on reasonable grounds and met procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Criminal history and drug use evaluated as indicators of subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness or unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of criminal behavior and ongoing drug use reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Clearance may be denied if reasonable grounds exist to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that marijuana use was irrelevant and insufficient reasons provided
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction for possession of stolen property
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister emphasized legislative purpose of preventing security threats

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide sufficient documentation for a 106-day period and had credibility issues
Residency_Compliance: 1,095 days required; applicant was 15 days short
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness and improper blending of residency tests
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Citizenship Judge
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Relief_Sought: Allowance of appeal and grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Strict application of the Pourghasemi test for residency
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for residency determination; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision was procedurally fair, no improper blending of tests, and ruling was reasonable
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court on appeal

Violation_Type: Exclusion from refugee status under international convention
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Application_Facts: Victor Kroon, a Russian citizen residing in Estonia since 1973, claimed persecution in Estonia despite having rights and obligations similar to Estonian nationals.
Claimant_Status: Russian citizen with long-term residency in Estonia
Residency_Compliance: Kroon had established residency in Estonia with rights akin to nationality
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal applied Article 1E correctly; no procedural error found on judicial review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian immigration authorities' jurisdiction to assess refugee claim despite claimant's effective nationality-like status abroad
Evidence_Used: Tribunal's findings on Kroon's rights in Estonia, duration of residence, and integration
Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; focus was on legal exclusion under Article 1E rather than credibility
Decision_Outcome: Application for refugee status dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Article 1E of the Refugee Convention – exclusion where rights and obligations of nationality exist
Decision_Rationale: Kroon enjoys rights and obligations in Estonia akin to those of an Estonian national, thus he is excluded from Convention refugee status under Article 1E
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for refugee status
Governing_Law: Administrative law principles on reasonableness and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed religious persecution in Sudan
Female Applicant raised gender-related persecution claims
No durable solutions were demonstrated in Sudan
Country condition documentation not submitted by Applicants
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by the Officer
Consideration of all relevant evidence
Procedural fairness in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Gender-related persecution claims lacked narrative support
Religious persecution claims not compellingly demonstrated
Decision_Outcome: Immigration application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer provided adequate reasons
Decision based on facts and law
No duty to provide country condition reports absent sufficient applicant evidence
Claims not substantiated in narrative

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose HIV status upon entry and visa renewals
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsections 44(1) and 44(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to disclose HIV-positive status during visa renewals
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to disclose material information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Preparation of inadmissibility report and referral for admissibility hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa application records, criminal record, disclosure history
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure on visa renewals
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review to challenge inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Severity of non-disclosure and criminal negligence conviction outweighed humanitarian factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons and reasonableness of inadmissibility report under Section 44
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction record and sentencing documents considered
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 44 allows inadmissibility reports for serious criminality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged inadequate reasons and unreasonable decision
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 44

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual(s) harmed due to negligent conduct
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence within the four years preceding the application; time spent studying abroad did not count toward residency
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required 1,095 days of residency
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The residency requirement ensures 'Canadianization'; absence from Canada for extended periods, including for study, does not fulfill the statutory obligation

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for only 173 days, falling short of the required 1,095 days; lived and worked in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence documented
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada as established in Re Pourghasemi
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement and provided adequate reasons; applicant failed to meet physical presence requirement

Application_Facts: Ghanuom family feared persecution in Lebanon and Israel based on past actions and affiliations
Procedural_Issue: Applicants claimed procedural unfairness due to the member forgetting notes
Evidence_Used: Decision dismissed claims of persecution as mere discrimination/harassment
Credibility_Assessment: Claims of persecution not meeting Convention standards
Decision_Outcome: Decision was reasonable and upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no certification of general importance
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's dismissal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness requires a fair hearing
Reasonableness standard applies to administrative decisions
Decision_Rationale: No confusion was evident; persecution claims deemed as discrimination/harassment not rising to Convention level

Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA Officer reasonably assess the psychological evidence and hardship claims in the H&C Application?
Governing_Law: Reasonableness is the standard for reviewing H&C decisions
Outcome: The PRRA Officer's decision was unreasonable due to insufficient consideration of mental health aspects
Credibility_Assessment: The PRRA Officer accepted the PTSD diagnosis
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mental health impacts, particularly PTSD, and emotional hardship upon return to Mexico
Application_Error: Failed to adequately analyze emotional hardships and implications of PTSD
Evidence_Ignored: Key aspects of the psychological report regarding emotional hardship
Legal_Standard: Hardship must be unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate
Application_Factor: Potential psychological deterioration if returned to Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for fresh determination

Governing_Law: Standard of review for H&C applications is reasonableness
Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer failed to properly assess mental health evidence
Evidence_Used: Psychologist's report indicating severe mental health issues
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to address impact of returning to Mexico on mental health
Credibility_Assessment: Diagnosis accepted but implications not assessed
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed and remanded for re-assessment
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual or disproportionate hardship
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate assessment of mental health evidence and hardship

Application_Facts: Applicant's testimony was vague, lacked specificity, and had translation discrepancies affecting credibility findings
Procedural_Issue: Interpreter discrepancies: interpretation was not continuous, precise, competent, impartial, or contemporaneous; inadequate interpretation affected procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Testimony of the applicant, interpreter performance records, Board's credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Translation errors leading to mistranslation impacting factual findings and credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's testimony lacking in credibility due to vagueness and translation issues
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status refused based on lack of credible evidence of persecution risk
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before the same Board member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to procedural fairness, including proper interpretation
Decision_Rationale: Mistranslation impacted the Board’s ability to make accurate credibility and factual findings; prejudice resulted from inadequate interpretation

Credibility_Assessment: efforts deemed insufficient by RPD

Risk_Assessment: risk of persecution or danger upon return
Credibility_Assessment: failure to fully pursue state protection undermined claim

Application_Facts: claim of past persecution and inadequate state protection in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: adequacy of efforts to seek state protection
Evidence_Used: documentary evidence on state protection in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: did not report all incidents to police
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found efforts insufficient
Decision_Outcome: refugee claim dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: well-founded fear of persecution
availability of state protection
Decision_Rationale: adequate state protection exists in Mexico despite corruption

Risk_Assessment: risk to life and personal security upon return
Credibility_Assessment: delay and lack of reporting weakened claim

Aggravating_Factors: occurred in context of broader violence
Risk_Assessment: risk of further victimization upon return
Evidence_Credibility: credible but insufficient engagement with authorities
Credibility_Assessment: efforts to access protection deemed inadequate

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer made a reviewable error in assessing humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 25(1)
Outcome: Application dismissed; no certification questions granted
Credibility_Assessment: Relevant due to mother’s omission as a public policy consideration
Evidence_Type: Emotional relationships, comparison of circumstances in China vs. Canada
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet family class requirements and lack of H&C justification
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mother's omission, reasonableness of officer's assessment, non-mandatory nature of country comparison
Application_Error: Alleged failure to properly weigh emotional ties and comparative hardship
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant claimed officer failed to weigh emotional relationships and cross-country comparison, but court found no error
Application_Factor: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, family class eligibility
Decision_Outcome: Denial of permanent residency application upheld
Authority: Federal Court (implied by judicial review process)

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas and sought permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds after refugee status denial
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants seeking H&C relief
Evidence_Used: Lack of evidence regarding FGM risk
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but claims not substantiated
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25(1)
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, except procedural fairness which is correctness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship demonstrated; legal test correctly applied

Crimes.Dispute_Type: H&C application following refugee claim denial

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence to support extraordinary hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Demonstration of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under Section 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to meet burden of proof for H&C relief

Crimes.Dispute_Type: H&C application after negative credibility finding and criminal history revealed
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer erred in H&C assessment or legal test application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by lack of disclosure and criminal history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family risk and integration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence and failure to disclose material facts
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose criminal history affecting admissibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Demonstration of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25(1)

Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of domestic violence in Canada and fear of her cousin.
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address the applicant's sur place claim despite evidence supporting it.
Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic violence in Canada, fear of cousin
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze sur place claim even though evidence was presented
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed the claim without addressing the sur place aspect
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition of refugee status based on persecution in Turkey and domestic violence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Board must examine sur place refugee claims if supported by evidence
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider sur place claim constitutes a reviewable error

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant, survivor of sexual assault in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Assault occurred after fleeing persecution in home country
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk from cousin in Canada
Risk_Nature: Threat of further abuse or retaliation
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on familial and gender-based dynamics
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but not analyzed
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence of abuse, fear of cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not properly assessed due to procedural oversight
Credibility_Assessment: Negative inferences drawn for not reporting abuse, but sur place claim ignored
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving personal safety
Legal_Issue: Failure to assess sur place refugee claim based on domestic violence
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies noted (e.g., non-disclosure to family), but sur place evidence not evaluated
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected credibility and dismissed claim
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear; partially met but not recognized
Credibility_Factor: Non-disclosure used to discredit, but context not fully considered
Legal_Rule: Board must examine sur place claims when evidence supports them
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of cousin, domestic violence in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to procedural failure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of abuse, relationship with cousin
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Victim_Status: Refugee claimant facing threats in Canada
Aggravating_Factors: Threats made by relative in context of prior abuse
Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of bodily harm
Risk_Assessment: Serious risk of physical harm from cousin
Risk_Nature: Continuing pattern of intimidation and violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence of threats and assault presented during hearing
Evidence_Type: Testimony about threats and assault by cousin
Evidence_Credibility: Not assessed due to Board’s omission
Credibility_Assessment: No analysis conducted on sur place claim
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Dhillon failed to provide sufficient economic or family ties to India, had no travel history, and most of his children lived in Canada.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate intent to comply with authorized stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted by Visa Officer
Evidence_Used: Lack of family ties in home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of intent to return to India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa Officer found applicant's intent to leave Canada doubtful
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must prove they will leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet burden of proof; risk of overstaying assessed as high

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate sufficient ties to home country
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer committed a reviewable error in rejecting the application
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant lacked proof of economic/family ties, income, and travel history
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate intent to return
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Most children reside in Canada; weak connections to India
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove they will leave Canada at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings; correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged reviewable error by Visa Officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of strong economic ties to India
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No obligation to conduct interview if application is insufficient

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer made a reviewable error in assessing risk of overstaying
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 11(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 179
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant perceived as high risk due to lack of ties to home country
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Concerns about potential overstaying due to insufficient home country ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Majority of children living in Canada; no strong economic base in India
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to show intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of travel history, income proof, and familial/economic anchors in India

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant met the three-part test for a stay of removal
Crimes.Outcome: Motion for stay of removal denied

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration applications, family ties, legal status history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Pending immigration applications and family separation

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Three-part test for stay of removal
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of non-compliance with immigration obligations
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in Canada beyond visa validity

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal reviewed via judicial review

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims deemed insufficiently supported

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Obligation to enforce removal orders promptly under IRPA
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Minister of IRCC

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possibly Warrant for Armed Robbery (not confirmed in Canada).
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of removal order based on criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for stay of removal given potential criminal history
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Motion for stay of removal during judicial review

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant sought delay based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record checks, immigration files, court affidavits

Dispute_Type: Refusal of landing and fairness of immigration decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the senior immigration officer's decision to refuse landing was in error and if the duty of fairness was breached
Legal_Provision: Requirement for inquiry by senior immigration officer upon refusal of landing; existence of alternative remedy via appeal to Immigration and Refugee Board
Basis_of_Claim: Refusal to land family members due to concerns about sponsor's permanent resident status
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of an adequate alternative remedy (appeal to the Immigration and Refugee Board)
Decision_Maker: Senior immigration officer; court reviewing judicial application
Assessment_Standard: Duty of fairness in administrative decision-making
Legal_Standard: Standard for availability of judicial review when alternative remedies exist
Application_Factor: Sponsorship of family members by permanent resident; deferred landing; subsequent inadmissibility finding
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of judicial review application
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (as alternative appellate authority)
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context, but not explicitly certified

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose sponsorship withdrawal constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application, set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Abdallah failed to disclose material information despite being informed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Phone call on June 21, communication with embassy, border entry records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding material fact about sponsorship withdrawal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose regardless of accuracy of third-party statements
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: IAD focused on inaccuracy of Embassy statement rather than applicant's knowledge
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether material facts were withheld inducing administrative error
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: IAD downplayed Abdallah’s duty to disclose known sponsorship status
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of omission and intent to mislead under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Knowledge of sponsorship withdrawal prior to entry
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No physical document fraud, but false representation through omission

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to disclose material change in sponsorship status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - duty to provide truthful and complete information
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant informed of sponsorship withdrawal but did not disclose at port of entry
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Sponsorship applicant seeking entry to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entry made without full disclosure affecting admissibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of IAD authority in assessing misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of June 21 phone call, sponsorship withdrawal notice
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct evidence on applicant’s belief about materiality
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s failure to disclose raises credibility concerns
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturning of IAD decision on misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Materiality and reasonableness of belief in non-disclosure
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: IAD erred in law and fact by misapplying Medel
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Appeal Division, subject to Federal Court review

Dispute_Type: Credibility dispute in refugee status determination
Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in dismissing the refugee claim based on credibility issues

Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to past physical abuse

Evidence_Ignored: Applicants alleged psychological evidence was ignored; court found it was considered but outweighed by inconsistencies
Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in account of abuse, psychological condition affecting memory
Decision_Outcome: RPD's dismissal of refugee claim upheld

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Membership in organization engaged in organized criminal activity
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 37(1)(a)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Credible evidence including surveillance and testimonies

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant qualify for a stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds?
Evidence_Type: Medical records, evidence of financial hardship, family ties, country condition reports
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Irreparable harm, best interests of the child, balance of convenience
Application_Error: Officer allegedly ignored hardships and failed to consider best interests of the child
Assessment_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Evidence_Ignored: Hardships related to medical condition, financial dependence on compensation, family ties in Canada
Legal_Standard: Test for granting a stay under H&C provisions
Application_Factor: Injuries preventing employment, risk of losing medical care and compensation, unsafe conditions in Nigeria
Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal granted

Violation_Type: Removal order following overstayed temporary resident status
Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration, refugee claim and H&C applications denied
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, permanent resident applicant under H&C
Procedural_Issue: Seeking stay of removal during judicial review
Evidence_Used: Proof of injury, inability to work, family ties, financial hardship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged failure by officer to consider key humanitarian factors
Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal granted
Remedy_Sought: Interim relief from removal based on H&C grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Risk of financial ruin, lack of medical care in Nigeria, best interests of child not considered
Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Immigration Division

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Violation_Type: Failure to depart after final removal order
Application_Facts: Refugee claim, PRRA, and H&C applications all rejected; remains in Canada post-removal order
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, removal order issued
Procedural_Issue: Application for stay of removal during judicial review
Evidence_Used: Medical condition, financial dependency, family ties, country risk in Nigeria
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer allegedly misapplied H&C test and ignored stepson's best interests
Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal granted
Outcome: Removal stayed until legal proceedings conclude
Remedy_Sought: Interim protection from removal based on humanitarian grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Risk of harm in Nigeria, loss of medical treatment, financial collapse, family separation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were previously rejected; they submitted a PRRA alleging religious persecution in Ukraine
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants seeking PRRA protection
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to pending removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged risk not sufficiently substantiated with new evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer assessed new evidence and credibility without re-litigating prior decisions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, applicant submissions, documentation from interested parties

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably weighed credibility and relevance of evidence, including from interested parties
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reversal of PRRA decision and grant of protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for reconsideration or declaration of invalidity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial risk of persecution established based on new evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claims were denied and applied for PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired visa and refusal of status renewal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None found; focus was on risk assessment, not fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA context despite prior adverse findings
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's supervisory jurisdiction over PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: New documents, country condition updates, personal affidavits

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns carried forward reasonably from prior decisions
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No objective basis to conclude applicants face a danger of persecution upon return

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and authenticity of claimed persecution risk

Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed but did not arbitrarily dismiss evidence from interested parties

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged religious persecution as Pentecostals in Ukraine

Crimes.Application_Error: None identified; officer properly exercised discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence outright ignored; some deemed insufficiently relevant or dated
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing, source reliability, and specificity of evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No finding of forged documents; concerns related to probative value

Crimes.Crime_Name: Religious persecution claim denial under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Denial of protection based on religious persecution claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA Sections 96, 97(1), and international refugee law principles
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution due to Pentecostal faith in Ukraine
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No subjective or objective basis for fear of persecution established

Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada, under federal immigration and refugee protection regime
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Christians, particularly non-Orthodox denominations in parts of Ukraine
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State able and willing to protect religious minorities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Generalized social discrimination, not state-sponsored or condoned violence
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but insufficient to establish personal risk
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate legal and practical protections available
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Societal prejudice without evidence of systemic persecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors and societal elements, not government authorities

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Credibility: Allegations not supported by sufficient evidence

Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's decision to reject Mr. Huang's refugee claim based on lack of Christian knowledge was unreasonable
Governing_Law: Supreme Court of Canada decision in [2008] S.C.J. 9
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Huang demonstrated reasonable knowledge of Christianity despite minor errors; RPD focused excessively on these errors
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision was found to be unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Knowledge of religious beliefs and practices as a factor in assessing credibility
Legal_Rule: Standard of unreasonableness in administrative decision-making
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution for membership in an underground Christian church
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected by RPD initially, decision later vacated on judicial review
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Huang's testimony regarding his religious knowledge and practice
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Defendant_Response: RPD argued that insufficient religious knowledge undermined credibility
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of RPD decision
Outcome: Application allowed; RPD decision overturned and matter remitted to a new panel
Legal_Provision: Section 96-97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Safety concern over working conditions in a correctional facility unit
Legal_Issue: Whether the Appeals Officer's decision to find a danger in Unit 4 is reasonable under the Canada Labour Code
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of an administrative decision
Evidence_Assessment: Testimony from frontline officers, lack of CCTV feed to MCCP, presence of horizontal bars hindering gun use
Decision_Outcome: Appeals Officer's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of the Appeals Officer's decision
Credibility_Factor: Frontline officers' testimony regarding safety risks
Legal_Rule: Danger is any current or future activity that could reasonably be expected to cause injury before the hazard can be corrected
Grounds_for_Claim: Safety concerns leading to work refusal by Corrections Officer Brian Zimmerman
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeals Officer's decision found to meet standards of justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of CCTV feed, structural design of Unit 4 with horizontal bars limiting officer response capability
Legal_Framework: Part II of the Canada Labour Code (Occupational Health and Safety)
Defendant_Response: Respondent (employer/Correctional Service) supported the Appeals Officer’s finding of danger
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn Appeals Officer's decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded to Respondent
Legal_Provision: Section 125(1)(z.13) of the Canada Labour Code
Authority: Appeals Officer under the Canada Labour Code, reviewed by Federal Court
